section.name: Spring Namespace Properties
section.p: In addition to the applicable UML Metafacade namespace properties which may also be used, this page describes namespace properties specific to this cartridge only.

tr.td: The location to which all service classes will be generated.
The location to which all service implementation classes will be generated.
The location to which a service locator will be generated.
The location to which Spring DAOs, and any support classes (including hibernate POJOs and their XML configuration files).
The location to which Spring DAO implementation classes will be generated (if there are any business operations modeled on any entity).
The location to which the Spring applicationContext.xml will be generated.
The package to which the extra non modeled spring types will be generated. (i.e. the service locator, etc).
No (unless service-locator has been defined). If not specified and service-locator has been defined, it will be generated within org.andromda.spring.

The name to give the class that stores the java.security.Principal that is made available to the spring POJOs. Note: that this class will not be needed if you're wrapping your spring service POJOs with Session EJBs (i.e. using the session-ejbs property).
The name to give to the generated service locator class.

The pattern to use when constructing an entity name. {0} is used to represent the entity name in the model, so if you specified a value of {0}Entity all the entities generated would have a suffix of "Entity".
JDBC Driver to make database connection
JNDI name of data source to use. (would be used instead of the connection properties, driver, username, password, etc).
URL for the JDBC Driver to make the connection to the database.
The transaction manager implementation used by Spring.
FactoryBean that creates a local Hibernate SessionFactory instance within Spring.
The name/path of the application context resource file (i.e. some/path/applicationContex.xml)
The name/path of the bean ref factory resource file (i.e. some/path/beanRefFactory.xml)
The ID for the Spring bean reference factory (used to load the bean factory when using the Session EJB wrappers)
The prefix to the give the implementation operations (i.e. the operations that actually perform the handling of the logic).
Whether or not to generate a default exception for each service. This exception will handle unexpected exceptions occuring within the implemented operations.
The pattern to use when constructing the default service exception name. NOTE: This propety is only applicable when defaultServiceExceptions is true.

Whether or not code for checking if a service or DAO operation parameter is required is generated. Its sometimes useful to turn this feature off if the tool you're using doesn't support stereotypes on parameters.

URI specifying the specific mappings from model types to hibernate types. (i.e. file:${basedir}/HibernateTypeMappings.xml). This is not necessary but useful for defining hibernate user types (when hibernate doesn't support a specific type in the manner needed for your application).
The package to which hibernate custom types contained within the cartridge should be output.
The default hibernate generator class. This is what is used if no @andromda.hibernate.generator.class is defined for an entity.
The value of the default-cascade attribute of the hibernate entity XML mapping.
Strategy for obtaining the JTA TransactionManager
The JNDI name of the JTA UserTransaction object
The fully qualified class name of the Hibernate TransactionFactory implementation
Whether or not to use outer join
Whether or not to log SQL statements
JNDI name bound to the SessionFactory.
Qualify unqualified tablenames with the given schema/tablespace in generated SQL.
A non-zero value determines the JDBC fetch size
Sets a maximum "depth" for the outer join fetch tree. eg. recommended values between 0 and 3
A nonzero value enables use of JDBC2 batch updates by Hibernate. ex: recommended values between 5 and 30
Whether or not to enable use of JDBC2 scrollable resultsets by Hibernate. This property is only necessary when using user supplied connections. Hibernate uses connection metadata otherwise.
Whether or not to use streams when writing / reading binary or serializable types to/from JDBC
Whether or not named parameters (i.e. ':someParameter') or unnamed (i.e. '?') parameters should be used in the HQL queries embedded within the model. NOTE: Does not apply to queries written in OCL.

Automatically export schema DDL to the database when the SessionFactory is created. With create-drop, the database schema will be dropped when the SessionFactory is closed explicitely. Permitted values are: update | create |
update
create
create-drop
Allows you to define new Hibernate query tokens. For example: given this a value of true=1, false=0 would cause the tokens true and false to be translated to integer literals in the generated SQL.

The location to which Spring Session EJBs will be generated, if this is specified, then session EJBs will wrap Spring service POJOs and transaction management will be handled by the Session EJB (instead of Spring). IMPORTANT: This enables Session EJB support, if you want your Spring service objects to be wrapped with Session EJBs then you need to specify this property.
The prefix to give to the Session EJB JNDI names (this allows the same Session EJB to be deployed multiple times in the same container)

If EJBs are being used, this specifies the pattern to be used when constructing the EJB package name (this allows a Spring Service to be wrapped by this Session EJB) and avoids name conflicts). The {0} character represents the service package name. This could be something like {0}.ejb which would create the Spring Session EJBs in the package ending in the ejb package.
If EJBs are being used, this specifies the view type for the EJB interfaces. Can be either local or remote.
The name of the security realm (i.e. animal-quiz, other, etc). NOTE:This enables EJB security if specified.
